{{The Holocaust sidebar}} The '''Wąsosz pogrom''' was the mass murder of [[History of the Jews in Poland|Jewish residents]] of [[Wąsosz, Podlaskie Voivodeship|Wąsosz]] in [[Nazi]] German [[Occupation of Poland (1939–1945)|occupied Poland]] that took place on 5 July 1941, during [[World War II]].
== Circumstances surrounding the pogrom == When [[Nazi Germany]] invaded [[Poland]] in 1939, the village of [[Wąsosz, Podlaskie Voivodeship|Wąsosz]] ([[Podlaskie Voivodeship]]) was taken by the Germans in the second week of the war.<ref name="Pinkas"/> At the end of September, in accordance with the [[German–Soviet Boundary and Friendship Treaty|German–Soviet Boundary Treaty]], the area was transferred by the Nazis to the [[Soviet Union]].<ref name="Pinkas"/>
The Soviet Union [[Soviet invasion of Poland|invaded Poland from the East]] two weeks earlier, on 17 September 1939, pursuant to the secret protocol of the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]]. The [[Red Army]] overran 52.1% of territory of Poland with over 13,700,000 inhabitants. The Soviet occupation zone included 5.1 million ethnic Poles (ca. 38%), 37% Ukrainians, 14.5% Belarusians, 8.4% Jews, 0.9% Russians and 0.6% Germans. There were also 336,000 refugees who escaped to [[Kresy|eastern Poland]] from areas already occupied by Germany – most of them Polish Jews numbering at around 198,000.<ref name="Trela-Mazur">{{cite book | author =Elżbieta Trela-Mazur | title =Sowietyzacja oświaty w Małopolsce Wschodniej pod radziecką okupacją 1939-1941 (Sovietization of education in eastern Lesser Poland during the Soviet occupation 1939-1941) | year =1997 |editor1=Włodzimierz Bonusiak |editor2=Stanisław Jan Ciesielski |editor3=Zygmunt Mańkowski |editor4=Mikołaj Iwanow | pages =294 | chapter = | chapterurl = | publisher =Wyższa Szkoła Pedagogiczna im. Jana Kochanowskiego | location =Kielce | isbn =83-7133-100-2| url = | accessdate =|language=pl}}, also in ''Wrocławskie Studia Wschodnie'', Wrocław, 1997</ref> Soon thereafter, the [[NKVD|Soviet secret police]] began spreading terror throughout the region. [[Polish prisoners of war in Soviet Union (after 1939)|Polish prisoners of war]] were massacred.<ref>Sanford, p. 23; {{pl icon}} [http://encyklopedia.pwn.pl/haslo.php?id=3950966 Olszyna-Wilczyński Józef Konstanty], [[Internetowa encyklopedia PWN|Encyklopedia PWN]]. Retrieved 14 November 2006.</ref><ref name="JOWIPN">{{pl icon}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/sled_bialystok_9.html |title=Śledztwo w sprawie zabójstwa w dniu 22 września 1939 r. w okolicach miejscowości Sopoćkinie generała brygady Wojska Polskiego Józefa Olszyny-Wilczyńskiego i jego adiutanta kapitana Mieczysława Strzemskiego przez żołnierzy b. Związku Radzieckiego. (S 6/02/Zk) |accessdate=January 7, 2005 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050107121610/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/sled_bialystok_9.html |archivedate=January 7, 2005 }} Polish [[Institute of National Remembrance]]. Retrieved 16 July 2007.</ref> In less than two years the Soviet [[NKVD]] conducted mass deportations of up to 1.5 million ethnic Poles [[Sybirak|to Siberia]],<ref name="HDoP">Jerzy Jan Lerski, Piotr Wróbel, Richard J. Kozicki, ''Historical Dictionary of Poland, 966-1945'', Greenwood Publishing Group, 1996, ISBN 0-313-26007-9, [https://books.google.com/books?id=FPxhOu_n1VYC&pg=PA538&dq=Jan+Czerski&lr=&as_brr=3&sig=OhNOwUDhsDLXsbQCr72HFxMjBfA Google Print, 538]</ref> with some of the local people collaborating with them, including some Jews who formed armed militias.<ref name="RP">{{pl icon}} The 90th session of the [[Senate]] of the [[Republic of Poland]]. [http://www.senat.gov.pl/k4/DOK/sten/090/22.HTM Stenograph, part 2.2.] A Report by [[Leon Kieres]], president of the [[Institute of National Remembrance]], for the period from 1 July 2000 to 30 June 2001. [[Donald Tusk]] presiding.</ref><ref name=Zimmerman67>Joshua D. Zimmerman, [https://books.google.ca/books?id=uHJyoGiep2gC&pg=PA65&dq=%22disproportionate+number+of+Jews+in+the+Soviet-established+institutions%22&hl=en&ei=tE2nTKyuN8WqngfH6dzCDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22disproportionate%20number%20of%20Jews%20in%20the%20Soviet-established%20institutions%22&f=false ''Contested memories: Poles and Jews during the Holocaust and its aftermath'' (page 65)], Rutgers University Press, 2003, ISBN 0-8135-3158-6</ref> There were also instances of [[Jewish Communists]] denouncing ethnic Poles to the Soviets.<ref name="ICP">[[Iwo Cyprian Pogonowski]], [http://www.pacwashmetrodiv.org/events/jedwabne/pogonowski.text.htm "Jedwabne: The Politics of Apology"], presented at the Panel Jedwabne – A Scientific Analysis, Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America, Inc., June 8, 2002, Georgetown University, Washington DC.</ref><ref>Tomasz Strzembosz,{{cite web|url=http://www.rzeczpospolita.pl/gazeta/wydanie_010331/publicystyka/publicystyka_a_2.html |title=“Inny obraz sąsiadów” |accessdate=June 10, 2001 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010610072611/http://www.rzeczpospolita.pl/gazeta/wydanie_010331/publicystyka/publicystyka_a_2.html |archivedate=June 10, 2001 }} </ref>
Following the Nazi German invasion of the Soviet Union, German [[Wehrmacht]] re-entered Wąsosz on 22 June 1941.<ref name="Pinkas">{{cite book | title =Pinkas hakehillot Polin | url =http://www.hashkedim.com/wasosz.html | year =1989 | editor = Abraham Wein | publisher = [[Yad Vashem]]| location = [[Jerusalem]] | accessdate =2007-03-17 }}</ref> At that time, 800 Jews lived in the town according to the one and only one existing deposition.<ref name="WZKH">{{pl icon}} Wojewódzka Żydowska Komisja Historyczna w Białymstoku, 14 VI 1946 roku.{{cite web|url=http://www.naszawitryna.pl/jedwabne_193.html |title=Relacja Menachema Finkelsztajna: Zagłada Żydów w powiecie grajewskim i łomźyńskim w lipcu 1941 r. |accessdate=October 14, 2010 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080420175710/http://www.naszawitryna.pl/jedwabne_193.html |archivedate=April 20, 2008 }} ''(deposition by Menachem Finkelsztajn; commentary by prof. [[Tomasz Strzembosz]])'' 47. ŻIH.</ref><ref name="MF1">Translation from Polish: [http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/grajewo/gra228.html "Reported by Menachem Finkelsztajn / Born in Radzilow, age 22 / Extermination of Jews in the Districts of Grajewo and Lomza in July, 1941."] The District Jewish Historical Committee Bialystok, June 14, 1946 No. 5/46. ''Publisher makes no representations regarding the accuracy of the translation.''</ref>
==The only existing document== The only account of what might have happened during the pogrom belongs to a document written by 22-year-old Menachem Finkielsztejn who had lived in the region with his parents [[Rescue of Jews by Poles during the Holocaust|under Polish protection]] during [[The Holocaust in Poland|the Holocaust]], before his subsequent emigration to Israel with his family and siblings. The paper, deposited in June 1945 at the Jewish Committee in [[Białystok]], was a rough and unsigned translation from Yiddish, with original, attributed to Finkielsztejn.<ref name=A-K /><ref name="AC">Dr [[Adam Cyra]], Auschwitz-Birkenau Museum, [http://www.naszawitryna.pl/jedwabne_186.html Zapomniana relacja] Nasz Dziennik, 2001-03-29</ref> His own estimation of the number of Jews burned alive in a barn in nearby [[Jedwabne]] was over ten times higher than what has been established by the [[Institute of National Remembrance]] (IPN) as a fact.<ref name="MF" /><ref name="glaukopis" /> Exaggerated stories such as the one written by Finkielsztejn, were encouraged by [[Central Committee of Polish Jews|CKŻP]] as possible backup for exit visas. They weren't utilized by CKŻP because of the free-passage decree issued by Gen. Spychalski.<ref name=D-H>Devorah Hakohen, [https://books.google.ca/books?id=hCw6v0TFhdMC&pg=PA70&dq=%22Poland+opened+its+gates+to+Jewish+emigration.%22&hl=en&ei=vZPlTILoE8uUnAey5NGjDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Poland%20opened%20its%20gates%20to%20Jewish%20emigration.%22&f=false ''Immigrants in turmoil: mass immigration to Israel and its repercussions...''] Syracuse University Press, 2003 - 325 pages. Page 70. ISBN 0-8156-2969-9</ref><ref name="yivo.org">{{cite web | url=http://www.yivo.org/pdf/poland.pdf | title=Poland. Liberation, Reconstruction, and Flight (1944-1947) | accessdate=May 12, 2011 | author=[[David Engel (historian)|David Engel]] | publisher=[[YIVO]] }}</ref> According to Finkielsztejn, the advancing German troops soon moved on leaving behind Nazi police presence. In the second week of the German occupation, a Polish militia was formed on the order of German gendarmerie. It consisted of "local thugs", wrote Finkielsztejn. On 5 July 1941 this unit surrounded Wąsosz to prevent Jews from escaping, and a house to house pogrom began.<ref name="WZKH" /><ref name="MF" /> The actual description of the pogrom remains unverified to this day and, as noted by Polish and American scholars, it might have been rewritten by Jewish custodians of the original document.<ref name="glaukopis">Prof. [[Marek Jan Chodakiewicz]], [http://www.glaukopis.pl/pdf/czytelnia/ResearchBeforeConclusion.pdf "RESEARCH BEFORE CONCLUSION: THE PROBLEMS OF SHOCK THERAPY..."] ''Collection 301'', page 5; ''Glaukopis socio-historical Journal'', 2007, {{ISSN|1730-3419}}</ref>
As Finkielsztejn writes – on 6 July 1941 the Jews who escaped from Wąsosz arrived in the neighboring town of [[Radziłów]], but the next day pogrom broke out there as well. According to his deposition 1,500 local and refugee Jews were burned there in a barn.<ref name="MF">Translation from Polish translation: [http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/grajewo/gra228.html "Reported by Menachem Finkelsztajn / Born in Radzilow, age 22 / Extermination of Jews in the Districts of Grajewo and Lomza in July, 1941."] The District Jewish Historical Committee Bialystok, 14 June 1946 No. 5/46. ''Publisher makes no representations regarding the accuracy of the translation.''</ref> However, there's also an early Polish monument on the outskirts of Radziłów which reads, "In August 1941 fascists murdered 800 persons of Jewish descent [undated], 500 of them were burned alive in a barn." The date on the monument is incorrect but historical research confirms that Jews were killed in Radziłów on 7 July how many, and under what circumstances, remains unknown. The pages from Finkielsztejn's paper describing the actual pogrom vanished from the Jewish Historical Institute of Warsaw in the following years.<ref name=A-K>Andrzej Kaczynski, [http://www.radzilow.com/rzeczpospolita.htm Thou Shall Not Kill] Rzeczpospolita, no. 159, 10 July 2000: "Nie zabijaj"</ref> According to the remaining page, the Germans found later, that allegedly only fifteen Jews were left alive in Wąsosz.<ref name="Pinkas"/> The Jews stayed in the town until June 1942 under the supervision of German gendarmerie who "behaved properly" (whatever it means); and were used by the Nazis for [[forced labor]] purposes. Finkielsztejn insisted that all criminals were Polish, even those who had Russian names, or were driving German tanks, while armed to their teeth by the Gestapo. His paper ends there. In November 1942 the survivors were moved to the [[Bogusze, Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship|Bogusze]] transit camp and in January 1943 sent to [[Majdanek]] or [[Treblinka]] [[extermination camp]]s.<ref name="Pinkas"/>
==Investigation== The crimes committed in Wąsosz are being investigated by [[Institute of National Remembrance]] of Poland,<ref>{{pl icon}} [http://www.ipn.gov.pl/portal.php?serwis=pl&dzial=245&id=148&search=52318 Sprostowanie do artykułu redaktor Anny Bikont] „Pięć lat po Jedwabnem” zamieszczonym w „Gazecie Wyborczej” z dnia 4-5.03.2006 r.</ref> under the direction of the IPN prosecutor Radosław Ignatiew who earlier investigated the atrocities in Jedwabne.<ref>{{pl icon}} [http://www.bankier.pl/wiadomosc/Sledztwo-w-sprawie-zbrodni-na-Zydach-w-Jedwabnem-zostanie-prawdopodobnie-umorzone-do-konca-marca-607328.html "Śledztwo w sprawie zbrodni na Żydach w Jedwabnem zostanie prawdopodobnie umorzone do końca marca"] Informacyjna Agencja Radiowa, 2003-01-21</ref> Ignatiew pointed to the role of the [[Gestapo]] agent Mieczysław Kosmowski a.k.a. "Gienek" (born 1913) renamed Walter Krause and paid 250 [[Deutsche mark]]s per month by the Gestapo for his denunciations of Poles and Jews in the [[Białystok]] region. The IPN chief prosecutor in Białystok, Zbigniew Kulikowski, named agent Kosmowski (last seen in [[Bydgoszcz]] in 1944), as the main instigator of the Nazi German raid on the Jewish community of Wąsosz.<ref>{{pl icon}} Adam Białous, [http://www.naszdziennik.pl/index.php?typ=po&dat=20090711&id=po01.txt "Niemcy płacili i za pogromy, i za denuncjację polskich żołnierzy"] Nasz Dziennik, Sobota-Niedziela, 11-12 lipca 2009, Nr 161 (3482)</ref>
According to Alexander B. Rossino, historian at the [[Washington Holocaust museum]], the atrocities committed in Radziłów near Wąsosz were likely perpetrated by the [[Gestapo]] paramilitary ''[[Einsatzkommando#Einsatzgruppe B|Einsatzgruppe Zichenau-Schroettersburg]]'' under SS-Obersturmführer [[Hermann Schaper]]. The methods used by his death squad in Radziłów were identical to those employed in Jedwabne only three days later – as shown by the evidence collected in [[West Germany]] between 1964-1976.<ref name="A-R">Alexander B. Rossino, [http://pogranicze.sejny.pl/archiwum/jedwabne/angielskie/rossino.html Polish "Neighbors" and German Invaders: Contextualizing Anti-Jewish Violence in the Białystok District during the Opening Weeks of Operation Barbarossa,] ''[[Polin]]: Studies in Polish Jewry'', Volume 16 (2003)</ref><ref name="T-U">{{pl icon}} Thomas Urban, reporter of the Suddeutsche Zeitung; ''text in Polish'':{{cite web|url=http://www.rzeczpospolita.pl/gazeta/wydanie_010901/publicystyka/publicystyka_a_1.html |title="Poszukiwany Hermann Schaper" |accessdate=November 24, 2007 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071124014038/http://www.rzeczpospolita.pl/gazeta/wydanie_010901/publicystyka/publicystyka_a_1.html |archivedate=November 24, 2007 }} , [[Rzeczpospolita]], 1 September 2001, Nr 204</ref>
